sen.j: のちに足利将軍を指す呼称となり、政庁を兼ねた将軍邸は後に歴史用語として「室町幕府」と呼ばれることになった。
sen.e: Then, "Muromachi-dono"(Lord Muromachi) became the denomination to point out the General ASHIKAGA (ASHIKAGA Shogun), and his government office-cum-residence was called "Muromachi Bakufu," which has been used after since as a historical term to indicate Muromachi Shogunate.

Later, "Muromachi-dono" became the designation for the ASHIKAGA Shogun, and his government office-cum-residence was called "Muromachi Bakufu," which has been used ever since as a historical term to indicate Muromachi Shogunate.

sen.j: 義満が幼少の頃の室町幕府は吉野朝廷との抗争が続き、さらに足利氏の内紛である観応の擾乱以来、幕政をめぐる争いが深刻さを増していた。
sen.e: When Yoshimitsu was young, there were constant struggles between the Muromachi Bakufu (Shogunate) and the Yoshino Imperial Court, and moreover, since the Kanno no Joran (Disturbance of Kanno), an internal conflict of the ASHIKAGA family, had occured, the strife for the government policies between the Shogunate and the Court became intensified.

sen.j: やがて政争で失脚した細川清氏などの有力武将が南朝勢力に加担し、1361年（正平 (日本)16年/康安元年）には清氏や南朝の楠木正儀らに京都を占領され、義満は赤松則祐の居城播磨国白旗城へ避難を余儀なくされた。
sen.e: Kiyouji HOSOKAWA and other potential military commanders supported the Southern Imperial Court, and in 1361(Shohei 16/ Koan 1), when Kiyouji and Masanori KUSUNOKI of the Southern Imperial Court occupied Kyoto, Yoshimitsu was obliged to escape to the Shirahata Castle in Harima Province.

sen.e: The Shogunate issued the order to hunt and kill Yoriyuki, but the following year, he was pardoned and after that was incorporated again in the administration with the post of shukuro, and during this period, on the other hand, Yoshimitsu achieved to establish his power as Shogun, and from these facts we can lead to the assumption that he might intended to make the two cliques, SHIBA and HOSOKAWA, to contain each other, by making use of their rivalry.

sen.e: In 1383 (Kowa 3/ Eitoku 3) became the first Genjichoja (Head of the Genjis) as the samurai class, and served concurrently as betto (supreme officer) of the Junan-in and the Shogaku-in, and later he was granted a title "Jusango," and reached to the top of the power of the samurais as well as the aristocrats.

In 1383 he was the first samurai to become Genjichoja (Head of the Genjis), and served concurrently as Betto (supreme officer) of the Junan-in and the Shogaku-in, and later he was granted a title "Jusango," and reached the height of power of the samurai as well as the aristocrats.

sen.j: 1392年（元中9年/明徳3年）には南朝勢力が全国的に衰微したため義満は大内義弘を仲介に南朝方と交渉を進め、持明院統と大覚寺統が交互に即位する事（両統迭立）や諸国の国衙領を全て大覚寺統の所有とする事（実際には国衙領はわずかしかなかった）などの和平案を南朝の後亀山天皇に提示し、後亀山が保持していた三種の神器を持明院統の後小松天皇に接収させて南朝が解消されるかたちでの南北朝合一を実現し58年にわたる朝廷の分裂を終結させる。
sen.e: In 1392 (Genchu 9/Meitoku3) Yoshimitsu accelerated the negociation with the the Southern Court with a help of the intermediary of Yoshihiro OUCHI, as the influence of the Southern Court over the whole national territory had declined. In the negociation, he presented the following proposals for the pacefic reconciliation: i) the emperor should be selected alterhnatively from the two imperial lincages, Jimyoin-to and d beDaikakuji-to (consistency of two lincages). ii) all the state-owned territories should belong to the Daikakuji-to from of the Jimyoin-to to requisition the Three Sacred Treasures which were in the possetion of the Empeor Go-Kameyama, aiming at an spontaneous disapearance of the Southern Court. By this way, he achieved the integration of the Northen and Southern Courts, and definitly put a stop to the 58 years' splited courts period

In 1392, Yoshimitsu accelerated negotiations with the Southern Court with a help of Yoshihiro OUCHI as an intermediary, as the national influence of the Southern Court was declining. In the negotiations, he presented several following proposals for reconciliation: the emperor should be selected alternately from the two imperial lineages, Jimyoin-to and Daikakuji-to; all the state-owned territories (of which there was actually very little) should belong to the Daikakuji-to; the Three Sacred Treasures which were in the possession of Emperor Go-Kameyama should be presented to Emperor Go-Komatsu of the Jimyoin-to, so that the Southern Court would be dissolved. In this way, he achieved integration of the Northen and Southern Courts, and put a stop to the 58 year split between the courts.

sen.e: In 1392, Yoshimitsu accelerated negotiations with the Southern Court with a help of Yoshihiro OUCHI as an intermediary, as the national influence of the Southern Court was declining. In the negotiations, he presented several following proposals for reconciliation: the emperor should be selected alternately from the two imperial lineages, Jimyoin-to and Daikakuji-to; all the state-owned territories (of which there was actually very little) should belong to the Daikakuji-to; the Three Sacred Treasures which were in the possession of Emperor Go-Kameyama should be presented to Emperor Go-Komatsu of the Jimyoin-to, so that the Southern Court would be dissolved. In this way, he achieved integration of the Northern and Southern Courts, and put a stop to the 58 year split between the courts.

sen.j: 義満と対立して後小松天皇に譲位していた後円融天皇が1393年（明徳4年）に死去し、自己の権力を確固たるものにした義満は1394年（応永元年）には将軍職を嫡男の足利義持に譲って隠居したが、政治上の実権は握り続けた。
sen.e: After the Emperor Go-Enyu, who opposed to Yoshimitsu and abdicated the reign to the Emperor Go-Komatsu, died in 1393 (Meitoku 4), Yoshimitsu established his power, and in 1394, he handed over the post of Shogun to his direct son, Yoshimochi ASHIKAGA and retired, but he continued to hold the real power.

sen.e: It is thought that he became a priest in order to obtain the competence with which he would be able to control the influence of temples and shrines, the remaining sphere he wanted to conquer, after he had reached the top of the most of the aristcratic spheres, as Seii Taishogun, and as Taisei daijin and Junsangu from the samurai class.

sen.j: 1399年（応永6年）には西国の有力大名・大内義弘を挑発し義弘が堺市で挙兵したのを機に討伐し（応永の乱）、西日本で義満に対抗できる勢力は排除された。
sen.e: In 1399 (Oei 6) he provoked a powerful feudal lord (Daimyo) in the west region, Yoshihiro OOUCHI, and with the excuse of Yoshihiro's taking up arms, he subdued Yoshihiro (War ofOei), and in this way, the influential cliques that might oppose Yoshimitsu in the west region had been eliminated.

sen.j: 義満は若年の頃から明への憧憬が深く早くから日明通交を望んでいたが、明側では南朝の懐良親王を「日本国王良懐」として日本における唯一の正規な通交相手として認めていたため、かなわなかった。
sen.e: Yoshimitsu, since his younger days, had deeply admired Ming, wishing to establish the trade between Japan and Ming. However, the government of Ming recognized the Prince Kanenaga as an authentic and sole counterpart to negotiate, therefore, Yoshimitsu's wish had not been fulfilled.

sen.j: ようやく明の建文帝によりそれまでの懐良親王に代わって日本国王に冊封され、明の大統暦が授与され国交が正式に樹立した。
sen.e: Finally the Jianwen Emperor of Ming offered an master-and-man relationship (sakuho) to the Japanese sovereign, in the place of the Prince Kanenaga with whom Ming wanted to have contact so far, and when Ming granted the Datongli calendar to Japan, the two countries' diplomatic relations was formally established.

sen.j: 明の皇帝に朝貢する形式をとった勘合貿易を1404年（応永11年）から始め、また明に要請されて倭寇を鎮圧した（なお、返礼の使者を送るまでに靖難の変が起き、建文帝から永楽帝に皇帝が変わっていた）。
sen.e: In 1404 (Oei 11), he started the Japan-Ming trade (Kango Boeki) that took a form of tribute to the emperors of Ming. Requested by Ming. He also achieved to suppress Wako (Japanese pirates). (However, before the Ming's goverment would dispatch an envoy to convey the emperor's gratitude to the Japanese government, the Seinan War had occurred in Ming and the Jianwen Emperor abdicated and Yongle Emperor took the throne.)

sen.j: 遣唐使の廃止以来、独自の小中華思想に基づく孤立政策を採っていた公家社会では明皇帝の臣下となる朝貢貿易に対して不満や批判が多くあったが、義満の権勢の前では公な発言ができず日記などに記すのみであった。
sen.e: Since the abolition of the Imperial Japanese embassies to China (Kentoshi), in the Japanese aristocratic society, in which an isolation policy was practiced based on the petit sinocentrism, there were accumulated discontents with and criticism to the Chokou Boeki (tribute trade) because Japan was treated as vassal to the emperors of Ming, but, as the aristocrats were not able to speak out publicly in the face of the Yoshimitsu's strong influence, they could do nothing but commenting their dissatisfaction in a diary or other documents.

sen.j: 明の文化に心酔していた義満は明の太祖・洪武帝にあやかって日本の年号にも「洪」の字を使うよう朝廷へ圧力をかけたが、上記の理由もあり朝廷側が拒否したため実現しなかった。
sen.e: Yoshimitsu who adored the Ming's culture, pressed the Japanese Imperial Court to use the Chinese character 洪 in the name of Japanese eras after the Taizu of Ming, Hongwu Emperor (洪武帝), but his intent was rejected by the Imperial Court for some reasons including the fact mentioned above

sen.j: 機嫌を損ねた義満は以後、逆に自分の生きている間には年号を変えさせなかったため応永年号は明治以前では最も長い年号となった。

sen.j: 田中義成、今谷明らは義満が皇位簒奪する意図を持っていたのではないかとする説を唱えており、これを受けて作家の海音寺潮五郎、井沢元彦らは義満の死が突然だったため、これは義満の皇位簒奪を阻止するための暗殺ではないかとの意見を提示している。
sen.e: Yoshinari TANAKA, Akira IMATANI, and others propose a theory that Yoshimitsu had an intention to usurp the imperial throne. and based on this theory, some novelists including Chogoro KAIONJI and Motohiko IZAWA present their opinion that Yoshimitsu's sudden death might confirm that he was assassinated to interrupt his intent of usurpation.

sen.j: 義満は早くから花押を武家用と公家用に使い分けたり、2番目の妻である康子を後小松天皇の准母（天皇の母扱い）ついで女院にしたり、公家衆の妻を自分に差し出させたりしていた。
sen.e: Yoshimitsu, from his younger days, was accustomed to use two stylized signatures (kao) according to the situation, one for the sumurai's affairs and the other for the aristocratic affairs. He also made his second wife, Yasuko, become the Emperor Go-Komatsu's junbo "fictitious mother"(treated as his real mother), then placed her as Nyoin (Wives of the former Emperors or princesses who could receive the same treatment with Emperors). He also forced the nobles to offer their wives to him.

sen.j: また祭祀権・叙任権（人事権）などの諸権力を天皇家から奪い、死の1ヶ月前の1408年（応永15年）4月には宮中において次男・義嗣の元服を親王並みに行った。
sen.e: He also deprived various authorities such as the authorities for retuals and for personnel affaires from the Imperial Family. In April 1408 (Oei 15), one month before his death, he carried out the ceremony of Genpuku (coming-of-age ceremony for boys) for his second son, Yoshitsugu, in a scale comparing to ceremony for a imperial prince.

sen.e: It is considered that all of these facts were projected by Yoshimitsu with the intention to usurp the throne, and Ming's hosaku of Japanese sovereign is also supposed to be planned as a part of his usurpation plan, in order to make good use of the eternal pressure over the imperial court.

sen.e: However, in any documents of that period such as nobles' diaries, there were no descriptions suspecting that the actions took by Yoshimitsu had been a part of his usurpation plan or he was assassinated, and therefore, they cannot offer any direct evidences of the usurpation plan nor the assassination of Yoshimitsu.

sen.j: なお、皇位簒奪とは義満みずからが天皇に即位するわけではなく治天の君（実権をもち院政を行う上皇のこと）となって王権（天皇の権力）を簒奪することを意味している。
sen.e: By the way, the usurpation here does not means that Yoshimitsu himself wanted to accede to the throne, but he wanted to usurp the authority from the emperors by way of acquiring the power as a sort of retired sovereign and intended to undertake the rule, holding real power even after his retirement.

sen.e: IMATANI supposes that Yoshimitsu was strongly influenced by China (Ming), but his instrument was not "Ekisei Kakumei," and he was making use of "Yamataishi," a prophetic verse popular that time.

IMATANI supposes that Yoshimitsu was strongly influenced by China (Ming), but he did not subscribe to idea that incumben emperors could be overthrown by decree of heaven, instead making use of "Yamataishi," a popular prophecy of the time.

sen.j: この詩は予言として知られており、天皇は100代現在では後小松天皇が100代目とされている。
sen.e: This verse is known as a prophecy, where it is predicted that the imperial reign would count 100 emperors, and according today's study, the Emperor Go-Komatsu is considered to be the 100th emperor.

sen.e: However, as it was not recognized the enthronement of the Emperor Kogun, Emperor Junnin, and Emperor Chukyo at that time, and the Muromachi Shogunate naturally viewed the Northern Court legitimate, the Emperor Go-Komatsu was considered to be the 99th.

sen.e: But, if an temporaly unification into the Emperor Go-Murakami realized by Shohei itto during the Knno no Joran (Civil war of Kanno) is counted, the Emperor Go-Komatsu is the 100th emperor.
